Smoke and Fire

Rising into the sky was a dark, black cloud of smoke that unfurled in the wind. Blade could see it from their house. The cloud was twisting and turning over the eastern side of the city. He watched it curiously and sniffed the air. He couldn't smell anything from here, but he swore he could faintly smell the smoke in the breeze.

Akir opened the door and came out, wondering what Blade was doing. He sidled along beside him and looked where Blade was looking. They weren't the only two looking over in that direction. There were many ferals stopped in their tracks, peering over the houses and buildings. Despite the desert being hotter than any place in the world, fires were extremely rare.

"Oh wow,” Akir said. "What do you think caught fire?”

Blade shrugged his feathered wings. "I don't know. It doesn't seem all that big though. Might just be a cart or two. Want to go look?” Akir nodded, so they leapt into the skies and flew to the east.

As they climbed higher into the sky, Blade could make out that the smoke was coming from the housing districts, and it looked like it was on the edge of the eastern-most part of the districts. A sinking feeling gripped his stomach the closer they got.

"A- Akir? That... that isn't...”

Akir looked very concerned too. They couldn't see much of anything beneath the malevolent black smoke as they flew over it, but they recognized the surrounding area all too well. They had found themselves living in this area for some time up until just a month or so ago. And Blade knew of only one wooden building around: Talia's house.

Blade's heart pounded anxiously in his chest as he dropped down and landed heavily. There was a crowd of two-legs around that peered at him uneasily, but Talia wasn't in sight. Akir landed shortly after, but Blade didn't want to wait around.

"Blade!” Akir shouted as Blade tore off toward the fire. Blade ignored him and slipped into the obscuring smog. He had to find Talia. He had to make sure she was alright.

He coughed and felt his eyes stinging as he got closer. The smoldering, burning smell was too pungent for his nostrils, making them burn. Flames flickered within the blackness that surrounded him. They flashed and caught his eye, sending a deep-rooted fear blazing in his mind. He trembled as the heat caressed his feathers threateningly.

Something snapped inside him, as if the fire brought a familiar sense of fear into his fleeting heart. He couldn't understand it, but he felt like he had seen a fire like this before. It was as if there were memories playing through his mind all over again, flickering through his vision just like the flame itself.

He stood outside the burning remains of Talia's home, hypnotized with terror. Thoughts passed his mind in the blink of an eye until he finally snapped back to reality. What could have caused this?

He winced as he listened to the roaring of the fire. Wood snapped and collapsed while the flames ate the house alive. He hoped and hoped that Talia wasn't in there. If she was, he knew she wouldn't survive.

Blade had no idea where the sudden courage came from, but he surged forward. He couldn't lose Talia; he couldn't lose the only other person in the world that truly cared for him aside from Akir. If she was in there, he would save her.

But just before he could get close enough to the burning building, Akir tackled him and pinned him down. "Blade! What the hell are you thinking!?”

Blade growled and tried to push Akir off. The heat was intense, and he could almost feel it scalding his feathers.

"I have to save her!”

Akir growled and firmly shoved Blade down as a loud crack sounded behind them and hunched over him. Blade watched in horror as the force of whatever collapsed sent flames billowing out from the solid doorframe several feet away. Akir fanned out his wings to protect Blade. Blade suddenly felt the heat of the fire leave his face as he watched Akir wince with pain and yelp.

Fear gripped Blade. He froze, his golden eyes lit with the dancing flames behind Akir. He could see them threateningly growing closer. Akir growled and dragged Blade away until they were on the other side of the street. He collapsed beside him, seeming to be trying to catch his breath, but there was too much smoke filling both of their lungs.

Blade still couldn't move. He coughed and wheezed, feeling sick to his stomach. His lungs and throat hurta stinging pain filled his head.

"You stupid idiots!” A familiar voice growled beside him. Blade broke free from his stupor and watched as Talia grabbed Akir's wings and tugged on them as she dragged him away. Blade meeped weakly and crawled after them, but it wasn't long before Talia came back and dragged him away too.

She took them out of the smoke in front of the growing crowd. Blade could almost feel their gazes focused on the two ferals and the two-leg helping them.

"Stupid, stupid, stupid,” Talia grumbled under her breath. Blade coughed some more while his head started to clear. His heart fluttered inside his chest rapidly, unable to stop as adrenaline coursed through him. Had he almost died?

He looked at Akir and horror gripped him. Akir's scales along his back were black. What were once deep-blue scales with a mixture of dappled purple blotches were now scorched badly. Blade whimpered and crawled over to him. Akir hissed and growled through clenched teeth.

"What were you two thinking?” Talia growled. "You almost got yourselves killed for no reason!”

"I... I was going to s- save you...” Blade said. He was too focused on Akir to see Talia's furious glare. He wanted to hold Akir tight and never let go, but after just a brief touch Akir hissed and growled with pain.

But he could hear her sigh. "Where do you two live? We need to get him out of here and treat his burns.”

Blade stared at Akir with worry. He'd never seen Akir hurt so badly... Akir never got hurt. It was always Blade who got himself into trouble, but this time Blade got Akir into trouble. He felt terrible. His stomach flipped around inside him and twisted itself into a knot as he trembled. Now he knew how Akir had felt, but he felt worse than that. This was his fault.

Without hesitating, Talia dumped the cart's contents and Blade helped her lift Akir into it. They wheeled it away after hearing a disgruntled wolf growling insults—the owner of that cart. Blade turned and growled back at him with his fangs bared. Intimidation wasn't Blade's forte, but he would do anything for Akir. Nevertheless, the wolf backed off.

"W- What are we going to do?” Blade asked anxiously, staring at the burns along Akir's back. A sick, twisting feeling gripped his stomach. Akir was in pain.

"I don't know. I need to make a salve to help his scales heal. He's fine for now, and he's at no risk of dying,” she assured Blade.

Blade nodded, feeling slightly relieved. "What do you need?”

Talia sighed. "This would be much easier had my house not burned down... I'll need lavender in whatever form you can get it, preferably oil. That's the priority, but I'll also need honey, coconut oil, and the sap of a Godswood tree. You can find all of these at an herb shop in the market district. It's a small building next to a jewelry and linen stall.”

Blade nodded again and grabbed his satchel with some money. He had Talia repeat the list back to him before he quickly left and took to the skies.

When he returned, Talia had placed wet rags along Akir's back. He gave her everything she needed, including a mortar and pestle he had also bought. He was proud of himself for thinking ahead on that, as he knew they didn't have anything like that in their home. She regarded him thoughtfully and started mixing the herbs together.

"How did this happen?” she asked as she stirred.

Blade sat down on his haunches. "He protected me from a sudden burst of flames... I... I was being stupid.” He gritted his teeth, remembering that this was entirely his fault. He wanted to go save someone who didn't need rescuing. He let his emotions get the better of him again, and Akir got hurt because of it.

"I must have been turned around when you two ran into the smoke. I heard gasps and shouts as two feral dragons ran toward the fire. As soon as I could I ran after you two, but I guess I was too late.”

Blade gulped and nodded. "I thought you were still in there...”

She shook her head. "No, I was out shopping when it happened. It was quite the surprise,” she hissed.

"How did it happen?”

Talia tensed. "I don't know... I didn't have anything that could cause a fire. I expected that house to collapse on its own before it burned down.”

"So it just caught fire?” Blade asked disbelievingly.

Talia pondered for a moment as if questioning herself whether or not to tell Blade something. "I think it was deliberate.”

Blade's ears flicked nervously. "Who would do that!?”

She shrugged as if someone burning her home down didn't even matter. "I don't know. It's just a hunch.”

SMOKE AND FIRE

Blade could see it from their house. The cloud was twisting and turning over the
eastern side of the city. He watched it curiously and sniffed the air. He
couldn't smell anything from here, but he swore he could faintly smell the smoke
in the breeze.

along beside him and looked where Blade was looking. They weren't the only two
looking over in that direction. There were many ferals stopped in their tracks,
peering over the houses and buildings. Despite the desert being hotter than any
place in the world, fires were extremely rare.

"Oh wow, Akir said. "What do you think caught fire?

Blade shrugged his feathered wings. "I don't know. It doesn't seem all that big

closer they got.

"A- Akir? That... that isn't...

area all too well. They had found themselves living in this area for some time
up until just a month or so ago. And Blade knew of only one wooden building
around: Talia's house.

heavily. There was a crowd of two-legs around that peered at him uneasily, but
